item.title: Takeaways from the Free Will lectures by John Conway
item.description: This is a quick summary of my main takeaways from the Free Will lectures given by John Conway at Princeton somewhere in 2009. Videos can be found on Youtube (each has a duration of 1 hour): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tmx2tpcdKZY https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LPa4nVL09D4 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nT-Ra8sc6-0 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Kf_BGNZG-Xw https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8TVZDY2aN6s https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IgvkhgE1Cps This is all about the Free Will theorem by Conway and Kochen. This series of lectures give a very approachable walkthrough of the proof for the theorem, as well as a pretty concrete confrontation to the philosophical consequences of such a theorem.

item.title: Notes on Alan Kay @ CodeX FutureLaw 2021
item.description: Alan Kay Alan Kay’s keynote at start of CodeX FutureLaw conference on 2021-04-08. Kay says we need to draw on atavistic tendencies, especially the need for stories to be made and shared (campfire image). I believe he is saying that trying to restrain (making humans fully rational agents) them is pointless. He believes explanation and learning assisted by computers is essential. Indeed, coronavirus pandemia and ongoing CO2 crises are wrongly understood, humans have failed to learn on things that matter.
